Black African-American descendants of slavery did not "hail" from anywhere, they were kidnapped and trafficked and should be justly compensated for such brutal treatment.

Native Americans can NOT be compared to European immigrants anymore than England should be expected to give up her sovereign claims because their original ancestors migrated across the North Sea from the main continent.

Thank you, cbd212 I feel like I'm living amongst heartless, hateful people when I hear complaining about paying for a safer life for children. One of the first things we teach our own children is being forgotten...share.

I work hard every day of my life for little pay, but I share what I have with others every day as well. Let's just be there for one another.
Fun puzzle, good job!

AFTER the drug wars Central America made about a billion babies (not really, but many). Now overpopulation will come to America. There used to be Liberals against immigration, the Sierra Club, but you never hear of them anymore.

Clearly John, you live in some parallel Universe where the drug wars have already ended. (I advise you to walk down some streets in South Chicago if you believe this).
The Controlled Substance Act was still heavily and unconstitutionally active here and in Honduras last I checked, sending DEA agents dressed as local law enforcement motivated by asset forfeitures to raid innocent homes, killing pregnant women in Honduras for answering the door. (Drug Policy Alliance).
But yeah, sure, the drug wars are over, and its all about those billion babies. You can take your prescription medication now.
The rest of us will self Medicate by Taxing drugs to Regulate and spend the Revenue to Educate.

"Migrants?" These children are called Drug War Refugees... Say it with me... DRUUUUG WAAAAR REEEFUUUGEEES... Entitled to LEGAL immigration through asylum... From A war that anyone who has either profited from prohibition or consumed illegal drugs is responsible for.
1000 National Guards at $12 million a month? What are the guards gonna do? Lay down and make a fence? Theyre not going to stop these kids who are only turning themselves in for safety. And if they do it will lead to violence and be all over the news.
Perry, once again, is making a fool of himself. He is only drawing more attention to the root cause of this wave of child refugees, and what is truly fueling the drug war... 45 years of Made to fail U.S. Drug policy.

I'm starting to see a (much less bloody) parallel with the intractable conflict in the Middle East.  America is like Israel, prosperous, strong, and actually have at lease some concern about the well-being of the children migrants.  The American public is split between return-to-sender hardliners and they-are-people moderates.  The children are like Palestinian civilians, ravaged by violence in their home but unable to integrate into America.  The coyotes and the gangsters are somewhat like Hamas, supposedly on the side of the children, but care for only themselves.
And as they crossed several countries, do you wonder why that didn't happen before? True refugees do not country-shop.

The Price of the Solution is Cheaper than the Cost of the Problem

It is becoming increasingly obvious the Republicans want to escalate a humanitarian crisis for purely political gain. Yes, we need a reasonable workable solution to two problems; a ineffective immigration policy and the lawlessness and hopelessness in countries south of our borders which is causing children to make a hazardous journey of hundreds of miles fleeing from terror and death.

Gov. Perry should know militarization of the Texas border with 2000 National Guard troops will do very little to stem the torrent of undocumented children and adults. What it will do is increase the likehood of some "Kent State" like tragedy, this time children not college students may be killed. But, what are few innocent childrens lives when an opportunity to curry favor with a rabid and radical minority constituency insistent on using bullets not brains, to resolve a crisis. Let just one of these refugee children be inadvertently shot or killed at the border by the Texas National Guard and our "immigration" problem will be replaced by something much worse.

Our Republic, once a giant of principled justice and compassion is reduced to a pigmy of bigotry, hypocrisy and fear mongering. These helpless children did not foreclose on your home, did not take your job. Your taxes were used to bail out Wall Street princes not homeless peons. Your dreams were stolen by elite countrymen not destitute foreign children.
Also, the fact that Ji is still in the race is an accomplishment in itself, given the time limits and the fact that the peloton moves at incredible average speeds (usually).

Cops show up en masse.Not to score some "loosies" but to break up a fight.Fight was over so Pantaleo and Damico didn't want the trip to go to waste and they picked on their favorite target: the "Big E".A low hanging fruit arrest and of course Pantaleo was itching to show how he could take down a man bigger than him.No probable cause for an arrest nor to take an individual briefly into protective custody.Big E presented no threat to anyone.Even though a Sargent was on the scene he must not believe he has any command responsibility but simply by stand.Even after Pantaleo put on a choke hold Big E had his hands up the whole time in a plainly submissive posture." I can't breathe" must not register with Pantaleone as a distress call since he adjusted and tightened his choke hold and then kneeled on Big E's head with unconsciousness  following.It seems NYC Police have not even been trained in CPR with chest compressions as no officer bothered to start CPR.EMTs obviously are trained the same-just feel for a pulse and load the carcass into the ambulance.I hope I never have a heart attack on the streets of NYC.Pantaleo is a bad apple who with his rash actions has cost himself his career - too much video evidence to sweep this under the rug.The chokehold was banned because it can go south and lead to death.Policing is an honorable profession and we owe the officers the safe city we have today.I hope they realize excising the bad apples protects them first and foremost.
Certainly there has never been a case of police brutality in Boston...
Please stay in Long island, where there is apparently no Mafia, no crime, and no incidents where there is violence between police and citizens.

Another well-informed comment.  Approximately 10,000 American a year are killed by other civilian with guns, thousands more are killed with other implements, and hundreds of thousands a year are maimed in assaults robberies, etc.  The Police are the thin line that has to prevent and respond to violence between civilians.  Scores of police officers also die in the line of duty--perhaps you missed the story of the young Hispanic police officer murdered in cold blood in Jersey city just for being a police officer.

Why couldn't the officers have first spoken to Eric Garner instead of grabbing him and then wrestling him to the ground? Haven't they been trained in de-escalating situations? Why must they always go first to force and exerting their power over someone who was no physical threat to anyone? This was an egregious display of mis-policing that rightly incited people against the police. The Us versus Them mentality never works. When will the police learn that? The fact that policemen who break the law by using the chokehold are not disciplined makes official approval of confrontational policing even more apparent. I watched the video and I think it was murder. Five policemen confronted one guy who could have easily been spoken to and quietly arrested if that's what had to be done. I found it very upsetting that the police used gestapo tactics when they were definitely not necessary. This happens over and over and civilians suffer for lack of training and sensitivity by the police. The officer who used the chokehold broke the law. Did he murder Eric Garner? Did he do it alone or did the officer(s) compressing Eric Garner's chest, mashing his face into the sidewalk and holding him down contribute to his death? There should be a REAL trial and there should also be a complete overhaul of policing methods.
For all the purpoted "annoyances suffered by store owners, a grown man is dead by 4 policemen for no reason. He is DEAD. It's bullsh*t is what it is.

Don't you feel, all "good intentions" aside, that there should be at the VERY LEAST a small measure of responsibility for the death of this man, when your actions, after he has claimed however many times that he can't breathe, have resulted in his death? So what they didn't "intend", they killed him anyway. So what, oh well, dock me a few days because -he didn't mean it? Seriously? As long as a cop says "I didn't mean it?" Really? It was an accident?

Lots of emotions being vented here, but little light being shed. Clearly, in most cases, those making comments have never worked on the law enforcement side. They have not heard the hundreds of complaints by store owners and residents asking them to "do something" about the petty crimes that make a neighborhood unpleasant and ruin quality of life. They have not seen the same guy they arrest or write summonses to back out on the corner every day blithely ignoring their demands that he stop violating the law. They have never had to face the adrenaline-fueled, tension-filled moment of having to physically restrain someone who refuses to be arrested, especially a giant of a man who weighs more than the two officers combined. They don't have to make snap judgments several times a day about when and how to engage in a physical confrontation that might end in serious injury for the officer or the suspect, nor do they face being second-guessed for either not acting or taking too much action.

For all the supposition and inflammatory rhetoric about "murder" going on here, perhaps we could also suppose that the police officers involved did not intend to injure the unfortunate victim, and especially did not intend to kill him. There should be and will be an investigation here. There may even be an indictment, if a grand jury hands one up. But it is unlikely that this case, as tragic as it is, qualifies as "murder,", or that a jury would convict, even for manslaughter.

If he had complied with the lawful order of the police officers, he would have been out of jail and back on the street by now, like the thousands of others before him. If selling loosees is ok we should make it legal. If the medical examiner finds chocking as the cause of death, then the officer should held accountable.

As former Chief Judge Sol Wachtler  once said, a good prosecutor could get a jury to indict a ham sandwich. But achieving a conviction for murder here would be next to impossible--and even a manslaughter conviction would be difficult.
Oh yes. If you sell loosies, you should be executed.

Guess you never worked as a cop before...when you have walked in the shoes of a police officer for a few years, then you can offer comments like this.

Very doubtful that a murder conviction could be obtained here, and there has been no death penalty in NY state since a court decision in 2004--and the last execution in NY State was more than half a century ago.
Ridiculous nonsense. We've learned more about the universe in the last 30 years than in all of history combined.

No one ever claims to have overheard God speaking to someone else, and Jesus has left us none of his recorded jokes about ourselves or the universe, so sceptics have a case that much at least.  Religion explains a lot about how we best organize ourselves socially to exploit scientific discoveries, but it tells us nothing how the natural world operates. Jesus was a carpenter, not a biologist. And none of his apostles were physicists or cosmologists.
Goswami's book, "The Self Aware Universe," argues this as well.  At one point as I recall he suggests that consciousness exists at the subatomic level.
In the middle ages he was an architect, holding a compass.

Since I can remember, I've felt there is consciousness in the universe, we have it, so it exists in the universe. Einstein said that if there is a God, he's a mathematician. And, he said, the most incomprehensible thing about the universe is that it is comprehensible.  Information recycled as new for the new ones reading it...  And hopefully new geniuses to figure the figures out for us.
Is math a product of the mind, or does math exist and the mind simply (!!) discovered it and described it?  My tilt is toward the latter.

And the converse is also true. If we consider adaptation and all it entails, then it seems reasonable that existence depends on imbalance, conflict and action. Stuff happening. Think of it as a weird kind of feast. Organic change, transformation and adaptation are fundamental attributes of life. Our senses serve to remind us that we are alive at this moment and life is ours to experience and do things. Get out of the office and take a long walk through the woods. See what's going on out there. Discover all sorts of trees and animals. Compared to them, we humans are some crazy monkeys. And I don't expect that human attribute will ever change.

It is my understanding that there is a thread of math in both music and art to mention a few.  The Universe, nature et al depend on balance. In order to function, when any entity gets out balance, the Universe brings it back to center. It's an equation.
New intelligent species arising after we are gone?  A very provocative idea.  Thanks

It is a general tendency of critics of scientists and their stunning achievements to be unaware that humans are not the most successful life form on this planet now, and will prove not to be over the long course of time, when we die off as other species survive. Those species, given time, will develop intelligence and social life and probably, science.

Scientists understand this, it's people like Nagel, who do not, that are arrogant.

That was described in his ascent by experience from amateur races (criteriums) to the professional races with skilled racers who function for the team's goals: in his case, to lead the pack at particular points, at others, he need only be concerned with time limits. These limits are standards of qualification; no team hires riders who can not meet the time standards and function within the team's goals; it would be hard to imagine a team hiring a rider for the Tour who is not a category 1 rider. (No doubt a quick search will provide a better answer about rider's qualifications for teams in the Tour.) His origins would not make him less qualified than any of the other riders who have been last, and should not come into play as a factor to ponder, especially as an either/or. Is that true for white NBA draft choices? The point being barriers are broken by merit, not by ethnicity (which historically, as been a barrier rather than an aid; note players in the Negro baseball leagues!)
